messageBody:
On 6/14/06, Vijay <vijay_nathani@...> wrote:
>
> Name the test class after the workbook. A simple script can take the
> name of the worbook and run the corresponding test.
> In JUnit, it is not necessary that the test case class name should be
> similar to the name of the class it tests.


This approach has two problems: one that Harsh already brought up (you need
to create 100 classes) and more generally, the fact that selecting the tests
to run should be a runtime concern. You should *never* need to recompile or
alter your Java code just so you can run different tests.

This is exactly why I introduced test groups in TestNG: once your code is
compiled, just include and exclude groups at runtime and you get exactly
what Harsh is trying to achieve.

--
